lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can listen to a video and answer comprehension questions about school life in the past.
supportStrategies: (Listening) Before watching, predict: “What was school like in the past?” Watch in short chunks and tick what was true.
stretchStrategies: Clothing Culture Gallery – After watching the Ghana video, students create mini posters comparing Ghana and Vietnam clothing. Add 1 idea for recycling clothes. Posters are displayed gallery-style, and students walk around asking: “What’s different?” “What can we do with old clothes?”

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can understand and explain how school life is different now compared to the past.
supportStrategies: (Social Studies) T-chart on the board: “Past” and “Now.” Students list 2 differences after the video, then share as a class.
stretchStrategies: Clothing Culture Gallery – After watching the Ghana video, students create mini posters comparing Ghana and Vietnam clothing. Add 1 idea for recycling clothes. Posters are displayed gallery-style, and students walk around asking: “What’s different?” “What can we do with old clothes?”

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can politely share opinions and discuss why some children still don’t go to school and how that affects their future.
supportStrategies: (4Cs – Discussion) Ask: “Why do some kids not go to school today?” Students pair and share ideas, then write one as a class response.

items: A wide variety of syllabus hobbies may be less popular or available to some Vietnamese students (practising the flute; seeing famous paintings), although many overlap
Hai con chó >> two dog [two dogs]. Not only the form, but the pronunciation is tough here, as it changes depending on the final sound of the noun [s,z,iz]

Unstressed vowels do not really exist in Vietnamese, so these need extra practice. Make sure the final vowel of computer is a light schwa, not a heavy com-pu-TER. Same with the final vowel of banana. Or the second syllable of elephant. And so on.

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.
